author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Ex-con boyfriend of Zymere Perkins' mother charged with murder
text:
The ex-con accused of abusing 6-year-old Zymere Perkins in a filthy Harlem apartment until the helpless boy died whined about his case as prosecutors announced murder charges against him Tuesday.
“I wasn't even in the house!" accused killer Rysheim Smith, handcuffed and slouched in his seat, blurted out to Justice Charles Solomon during a short bail hearing in Manhattan Supreme Court.
Smith, 42, in addition to complaining that his court-assigned homicide lawyer isn't working to his liking, broadcast his pathetic defense to Zymere's killing before Solomon shut him down.
"What did I tell you about talking about the case?" said the judge, who told Smith he should stick to his counsel complaints because any comments about the case could be used against him.
De Blasio defends ACS to state lawmakers, calls portrayal unfair 
"If you go to trial, whatever you say now, the people can introduce in front of a jury," Solomon said. "So don't say anything."
Assistant District Attorney Kerry O'Connell said a grand jury indicted Smith for second-degree murder and first-degree manslaughter.
"Mr. Smith is alleged to have frequently beaten Zymere Perkins with a broomstick and other objects as well as punched him in the ribs and other places throughout his body," O'Connell said of the tragic case.
Prosecutors claim 6-year-old Zymere Perkins “succumbed to the constellation of his injuries which resulted in his death by fatal child abuse syndrome.” (Facebook) The grand jury heard evidence of how Zymere "succumbed to the constellation of his injuries which resulted in his death by fatal child abuse syndrome," the prosecutor added.
Mother of 6-year-old Zymere Perkins faces manslaughter charge 
Solomon granted her request to hold Smith without bail, a revocation of the $250,000 bail that was set when he was facing lesser charges for endangering the welfare of a child.
Smith will get a new lawyer when he's back in court next week for his formal arraignment on the indictment.
His current attorney Norman Williams told the judge that his relationship with his client "has deteriorated" over the past "week or so."
"I asked to see the grand jury and he forced an indictment on me!" Smith railed, apparently failing to grasp the process and his attorney's role.
Parents shocked Brooklyn day care worker fatally beat her son 
Solomon asked if he meant that he had wanted to testify before the grand jury and the flustered defendant said he did.
Geraldine Perkins (pictured with Zymere) was charged with manslaughter and has apparently entered into a deal with prosecutors. (Geraldine Perkins/via Facebook) "You should understand the lawyer — not the defendant — makes the decision whether or not the client should testify," the judge patiently explained.
Only in very rare instances is it considered a good move to have a defendant go before a grand jury, especially in such a serious case.
Whatever the defendant would say in front of the secret panel gets produced as evidence at trial.
Dead toddler's case shows 'systemic' problems at ACS: report 
Smith was living with Zymere’s mother, Geraldine Perkins, in a roach-infested apartment without electricity on W. 135th St. on Sept. 26 when he allegedly attacked the child for the last time — highlighting the widespread problems with ACS’s handling of child-abuse cases.
Perkins, 26, was charged with manslaughter and has apparently entered into a deal with prosecutors. She previously pleaded not guilty in a sealed courtroom, records show.
Perkins told investigators that after unleashing fury on the defenseless boy, her hot-headed boyfriend hung him on the bathroom door and stormed out of the home.
She didn't bring him to the hospital until hours later by her own admission, court papers say.
